title: Cybersecurity (Amendment) Draft Bill 2025
summary: This bill proposes significant amendments to Ghana's existing cybersecurity framework, with far-reaching implications for technology companies, digital infrastructure providers, and individual users. The amendments introduce new compliance requirements, data localization mandates, and expanded government oversight powers.

innovation.description: Increased compliance costs and data localization requirements will significantly burden tech startups and SMEs. New certification requirements may create barriers to entry for new market participants.

freedomOfSpeech.description: Expanded content monitoring requirements and vague "harmful content" definitions could lead to over-censorship and self-censorship by platforms.

privacy.description: Mandatory data retention periods and government access provisions weaken user privacy protections. Lack of judicial oversight for data requests is concerning.

business.description: Data localization and infrastructure requirements will significantly increase operational costs. Compliance timelines may be unrealistic for many businesses.

keyConcerns.title: Vague Definitions Enable Overreach
keyConcerns.description: Terms like "national security" and "public interest" lack clear definitions, allowing arbitrary interpretation. This creates uncertainty for businesses and risks abuse of government access powers.

keyConcerns.title: Data Localization Requirements Are Unrealistic
keyConcerns.description: The 18-month timeline to build or lease server infrastructure in Ghana is insufficient for most companies. Small startups and international services may simply exit the market rather than comply, reducing consumer choice.

keyConcerns.title: No Judicial Oversight for Data Access
keyConcerns.description: Government agencies can demand user data without a warrant or court order. The 48-hour compliance window leaves no time for legal challenge, and users are not notified when their data is accessed.

keyConcerns.title: Excessive Compliance Costs Kill Startups
keyConcerns.description: New certification and audit requirements impose costs that established companies can afford but early-stage startups cannot. This creates barriers to entry that protect incumbents while stifling innovation in the tech sector.

keyConcerns.title: Retroactive Application Creates Legal Chaos
keyConcerns.description: The bill applies to existing services and data already collected, forcing companies to retroactively comply with new standards. This creates impossible situations for businesses operating under previous legal frameworks.

keyConcerns.title: Platform Liability Threatens Free Expression
keyConcerns.description: Platforms can be held liable for user-generated content, incentivizing over-moderation and censorship. The lack of safe harbor provisions means platforms will delete content preemptively to avoid penalties.

keyConcerns.title: Unclear Penalties
keyConcerns.description: The bill references penalties without specifying amounts or ranges, creating legal uncertainty. Companies cannot assess risk or budget for potential compliance failures.

provisions.title: Definitions and Scope
provisions.plainLanguage: This section expands the definition of "cybersecurity service provider" to include social media platforms, cloud services, and any digital infrastructure operating in Ghana. The vague language means even small tech startups could be classified as service providers requiring full compliance.
provisions.rawText: For the purposes of this Act, "cybersecurity service provider" means any person, entity, or organization that provides, operates, or maintains information and communication technology infrastructure, digital platforms, cloud computing services, social media platforms, or any electronic communication service within the territory of Ghana or serving Ghanaian users, regardless of physical presence...

provisions.title: Data Localization Requirements
provisions.plainLanguage: All companies processing Ghanaian user data must store it on servers physically located in Ghana. This applies to customer information, transaction records, user-generated content, and metadata. Companies have 18 months to comply from the date this law passes.
provisions.rawText: Every cybersecurity service provider shall ensure that all personal data, transaction data, metadata, and user-generated content collected from or relating to persons within Ghana is processed and stored within the territorial boundaries of Ghana. Compliance with this provision shall be achieved within eighteen (18) months from the commencement of this Act...

provisions.title: Government Access and Enforcement
provisions.plainLanguage: Government agencies can request access to user data without a warrant in cases of "national security" or "public interest" (terms not clearly defined). Service providers must comply within 48 hours or face penalties. There is no requirement for judicial oversight or user notification.
provisions.rawText: Where the Minister or any designated government agency determines that access to data is necessary for national security, public interest, or the prevention of cybercrime, a cybersecurity service provider shall, upon written notice, provide such access within forty-eight (48) hours.
